I do:

1L of water + salt in AM

Walk or yoga

12pm Meal 1: Egg, avo, kale, dressing, pumpkin seeds, almonds

Lunch walk

3pm Meal 2: Yogurt, PB, chia seeds, whey 

5pm workout (weights + Z2 or HIIT)

7pm Meal 3: Chick or beef, lots of veggies, black beans, berries

10pm bed

18/

Recap

- Pick a window that works for your goals & life, -1 hour
- Sustainable > Optimal, stay consistent
- No food until 1 hour after waking or 3 hours before bed
- Spend 7 days transitioning, stick to it for at least 30 
- >25 g protein for meal 1
- Resistance training

17/

Bonus:

Study on benefits of IF: https://t.co/bFs70Xugiw

16/

Tips:

Wearing a CGM will help you optimize sleep, exercise, around your window 

(ex if blood glucose is still high late while sleeping, you may consider an earlier or low-carb dinner, or after dinner walk)

Track weight and body fat to ensure you aren't losing muscle

15/

Tips:

The 7-day transition period and 30-day minimum are key! You want to give your body time to adapt 

To avoid muscle loss, make sure you do resistance training and eat adequate protein

14/

Tips:

Don’t obsess over breaking your fast - water, tea, and coffee are ok. Don’t overthink it. 

This is a lifestyle, it will only work if you make it tolerable

If eating a healthy, whole food diet, you may need more salt doing IF 

I add a pinch to my water in the AM

13/ 

Macros:

For meal 1, get >25 g of protein and keep carbs low (unless you work out right before/after)

Make sure your macros align with your exercise schedule and health goals 
(ex: I do intense exercise in the late afternoon and have a slow-carb at dinner)

12b/ 

BUT I’ve seen people do everything, so find what works best for your goals and your lifestyle

Exercise timing in particular seems very individualized

Being fat-adapted or keto makes this less of an issue

12a/ 

Exercise:

Light exercise (cardio) while fasting is more tolerable b/c you’re able to use fat stores for energy

Intense exercise can be done during the feeding window when more energy is available OR at the end of a fasting window when you can quickly replenish  glucose

11/ 

Implement:

Pick your schedule and start time 

Use a 7 day transition period, adjusting <1 hour each day- this reduces the chance of headaches, etc

Track macros & calories 

Track schedule w/ @zerofasting 

Stick to it for at least 30 days to let your body adapt

10/

2 non-negotiables to maximize the benefits for any schedule:

No eating until at least 1 hour after waking or 2-3 hours before bed. You want to take advantage of sleep-related fasting

Stick to the same schedule every day/week - consistency, consistency, consistency

9/

When considering your window (say it’s 8 hours) subtract 1 hour. For instance, 12-8 becomes 12-7 pm. 

When life gets in the way, you’re less likely to go past your window

8/

Once you pick your schedule - decide when to start your window:

Insulin sensitivity is higher in the morning and you absorb protein more effectively, but that means skipping dinner, which can be anti-social. 

That’s one reason most people pick 12-8 pm or 4-8 pm

7/

20:4 and OMAD 

Pros:
Less to think about with 1-2 meals per day
Potentially more weight loss

Cons:
Can be anti-social
People tend to overeat in the four-hour range
Muscle loss is more likely

6/ 

16:8 - one of the most popular, you eat in an 8-hour window, fast for the rest

Pros: 
Plenty of time to get in calories and protein
Little disruption to life if timed correctly
Minimizes muscle loss

Cons:
Hard to not watch the clock at first
Some people love breakfast

5/ 

5/2 - Eat a week of calories in 5 days, 2 days fasted 

Pros: 
Less thinking (no checking your watch for when to eat)
No meal skipping on eating days
Easy to avoid social meals on 2 days/week

Cons: 
Some struggle with a 48 hour fast  
Life events can disrupt the schedule

4/ 

Four of the most popular types:

5/2  

16:8 

20:4

OMAD (one meal a day)

3/ 

First, you want to pick a fasting schedule that aligns with:

1. Your life
2. Your health goals 

Otherwise, you will fail

2/

If you’re reading this, you may have tried and failed with IF, or it's your first attempt

So here’s a simple guide to make it a sustainable habit

1/

Intermittent fasting (IF), also called time-restricted eating, limits your calorie intake to a specific window during the day or week

There are 100s of threads on the benefits of fasting

But most people fail to make it a habit 

Here's how you can make it stick

I cover:

- Types of IF
- How to choose
- Protocol 
- Tips

@austinschless @PeterAttiaMD @Levels @veristable @supersapiensinc @UltrahumanHQ @hellojanuaryai @nutrisenseio 21/ Disclaimer

What I've done here is draw together a simple plan based on my CGM experience and widely available resources

Don't do anything drastic

I'm not a doctor and this isn't medical advice (obviously)

Talk to your doctor, they love this stuff

@austinschless @PeterAttiaMD @Levels @veristable @supersapiensinc @UltrahumanHQ @hellojanuaryai @nutrisenseio 20/ SUMMARY

Metabolic fitness protocol:

Eat slow carbs, never alone
Get at least 35g fiber
Consume healthy fats, first
Eat slowly 
Get cold or get moving after meals
Strength train 
Fast sometimes
Get sleep & de-stress
Measure

@austinschless 17/ MEASURE

You don't need a CGM for this test - they can be expensive

I recommend at least doing a before-and-after HbA1c test, which can be requested through your doctor

I'm requesting a blood lipid panel as well due to the increase in fats

@austinschless 16/ AVOID

Alcohol can really mess with your blood sugar - use in moderation

Low-quality fats like seed oils 

High glycemic index fruits (grapes are notorious)

Inactivity - I can eat carbs and go for a walk and be fine. No walk? REKT. Just move

15/SLEEP AND STRESS

Is there anything that these two don't influence?

Nope.

@austinschless has your sleep guide: https://t.co/Uf4u1ftoqn

I meditate and don't take life too seriously for the stress

14/ FASTING

One benefit of fasting is re-teaching our bodies to effectively shift between fat and carbs for energy. It also increases insulin sensitivity.

All good things for metabolic health

I'm going to try a 16:8 time restriction (eat only between 12 pm - 8 pm)

13/ EXERCISE

Each metric in metabolic fitness can be improved with different types of exercise

Resistance training has a direct effect on insulin sensitivity & more muscle mass increases resting metabolic rate 

A combo of HIIT, steady-state, and strength training is optimal

12/ GET COLD AND GET MOVING

This has been the biggest eye-opener 

A cold shower after breakfast (a part of my routine anyway) has a HUGE effect on softening the glucose spike

So does taking a 20-30 minute walk after meals 

Standing for 1-2 hours after has a similar effect

11/ ORDER MATTERS

If you're going to consume carbs, eat the fats & proteins on the plate first - it will soften the spike

Ever wonder why they have free bread at restaurants? The spike stimulates your appetite and makes you crave more so you spend $ on the big items

+ EAT SLOW

10/ FIBER

Fiber slows down digestion and is great for your gut - both help even out your blood sugar

Most Americans get 10g per day (yikes)

You should shoot for ~35+ (some recommend up to 50g)

How? Eat fruit, don't drink it + plenty of veggies, beans, nuts, & seeds

9/ MEAL COMPOSITION 

You can reduce the impact of your carbs by pairing with protein and/or healthy fats

Grabbing some a banana? Have some almonds as well

Need carbs in the morning? Add eggs

i.e. -> NO NAKED CARBS

8/ CARBS

Everyone knows that sugar and processed carbs suck

But I've found through my CGM that potatoes (white and sweet) and rice wreck me

Consider a CGM to find your best/worst carbs

7/ CARBS

Cut back to low carb/slow-carb only, then gradually introduce others

Month 1: stick to lentils, beans, legumes, berries
Month 2: add back barley, steel-cut oats, tropical fruit
Eventually: rice, bread, potatoes, & pasta (on rare occasions)

6/ Thus, an ideal metabolic fitness program:

Decreases variability, spiking, and average glucose while increasing our insulin sensitivity. 

This program has 3 prongs - you can use any or all (or none, it's your life)

1 - What you eat
2 - How you eat it 
3 - Everything else

5/ High insulin levels from glucose spikes and decreased insulin sensitivity (i.e. takes more insulin to do the job) is one of the reasons being metabolically unfit leads to so many health issues - not just diabetes

4/ Related is your insulin level

ELIF: Insulin is a hormone released by the pancreas in response to glucose. It's what allows glucose to enter the cell, either for use or storage

3/ Metabolic fitness has layers, but one we can measure and influence ourselves is our blood glucose level

ELIF: We want subtle ups and downs for blood sugar during the day after meals, not spikes and crashes, plus a moderately low baseline when fasting

2/ Poor metabolic health can result in,

Fatigue & Brain fog
Depression & Anxiety
Cardiovascular disease 
Poor athletic performance
Infertility or erectile disfunction
And a general increase in mortality

Not good.

1/ "I must be metabolically fit," I thought

I train 6 days a week and my body fat is 15%

But I purchased a continuous glucose monitor (CGM) because I like tech and was curious 

Turns out, I'm in that 88% unfit group too

Are you metabolically fit? 

Think again

Only 12% of the US is

Even if you're an athlete, you're likely in the 88% unfit group

I'm sharing what I've learned and my protocol to get fit

Let's do it together for better:

Focus
Energy
Longevity
Cardiovascular health
and more

For what it's worth @mattizzo preferred cold turkey - so there is no black and white approach

Why taper? 

2 reasons

@JamesClear writes that you don't eliminate a bad habit, you replace it. I wanted the ritual of coffee - the warm beverage in the morning - just in a different form

Caffeine is a drug and quitting overnight can cause withdrawal symptoms like headaches

I decided to go for a tapered approach - switching to yerba mate to start. 

It has significantly less caffeine as well as L-theanine which makes the experience feel smoother than the spike of a strong coffee

(I also really enjoyed the taste)

Is it improving my life or just returning me to baseline?

Was I comfortable being dependent on a drug?

Finally, my deep sleep numbers are terrible and I was looking for any solution

I started to wonder...

What about eliminating coffee entirely?

I immediately felt better during the day (more alert in the morning and no drop-off in the afternoon) plus I fell asleep faster

If you can half the dose of something and feel better, do it.

You can see this creates a tough cycle of dependency 

It led me to this protocol for cutting my coffee intake in half: https://t.co/8mS4HoEhq1

In addition, because caffeine has a half-life of ~6 hours, it stays in your system for a long time. 

A cup of coffee at noon is like drinking a quarter cup at midnight. This can delay the onset of sleep and crush your deep sleep.

You wake up tired and drink more

Think of a spout slowly filling a glass. Caffeine blocks the spout but doesn't clear it. 

That means when the caffeine wears off, all that built-up adenosine rushes in at once. That's why you can get a caffeine "crash"
Caffeine works, in part, by blocking adenosine receptors - delaying that sleepiness feeling.

Key takeaway: Starting in the morning, a chemical in our brain called adenosine starts to gradually build up. 

By the end of the day, the accumulation of adenosine creates a sleep "pressure." 

Wakefulness areas deactivate and sleepiness areas activate - putting you to sleep

I heard @sleepdiplomat discuss caffeine's role in sleep when he went on @hubermanlab and @PeterAttiaMD's podcast 

(I'll use coffee and caffeine interchangeably in this post for convenience, but other forms apply)
I've also been heavily focused on improving my sleep this year and often find myself losing energy around 3 pm

I got interested in quitting coffee when I read @michaelpollan's "This Is Your Mind on Plants" 

He was inspired to quit while writing the caffeine chapter of the book. He was told he wouldn't be able to understand the impact of caffeine on his life until he went without it

13/
BONUS
Stuck in a rut and want a healthy dopamine boost? Take a cold shower. The increase in dopamine can last days and the feeling of "overcoming" to do something hard creates powerful momentum

Still stuck? Do a "fast" from dopamine drivers like your phone to recharge

12/
SUMMARY
With dopamine, we want nice rolling hills with the occasional peak. This keeps our baseline high. Think rural countryside, not the Himalayas. 

Result: more focus and drive throughout the day, more pleasure from simple things, and fewer cravings for cheap hits

11/
CAFFEINE
Use that to your advantage when you need it, but avoid it in high dopamine activities, like social media or video games, to prevent the spike and subsequent dive bomb. Use the intermittence rule. 

Scrolling Twitter with your morning coffee can ruin your whole day

10/
CAFFEINE
I think even smelling the brew or taking the first sip releases dopamine (any coffee drinker can relate). Caffeine itself though doesn't increase dopamine

BUT it does influence the dopamine receptors, making the impact of the dopamine hit more intense

9/
INTERMITTENCE 
This is where the "Siri, flip a coin" thing comes in. If you only intermittently spike dopamine, you are less likely to fall into the trap of needing to continuously "one-up" yourself. This allows you to layer sometimes if you need a boost (music on a long run)

8/
REWARDS
Instead of rewards, build the narrative that you enjoy the activity for the sake of it, that hard work and the assignment is intrinsically good (think of a difficult activity you enjoy, like hiking, and find that headspace) Sounds like a stupid trick, but it works

7/
REWARDS
For hard things, like a work assignment, a reward might seem like a good idea. Rewards may increase dopamine but the pleasure is associated with the reward, not the assignment, making the drive to do the assignment even lower. Your brain won't "seek" pleasure from it

6/ 
LAYERING
The next time you try that activity, you'll need to increase the intensity even further to feel good.

That's why I cut music from workouts. I focus on the workout itself and the satisfaction it brings

5/
LAYERING
By "layering" pleasurable activities together, like listening to your favorite band while you working out, you create a surge in dopamine - that's followed by a depressed baseline, which can persist

Motivation and focus drop

Urges for easy dopamine increase

4/
But pleasure (peak) comes w/ pain (valley). A bigger peak -> a deeper valley

Easy dopamine hits like junk food or social media exaggerate this swing

Motivation & focus drop, cravings for another easy hit (junk food) increase
enjoyment in other activities (running) decreases

3/
Principles applied from the pod

Dopamine is "the currency of foraging and seeking"

It kept hunter-gatherers searching for berries

We have a baseline dopamine level. A healthy level keeps us focused & motivated

We also get dop. spikes for food, sex,  etc - we feel pleasure

2/
In addition - some hard and fast rules:

No phone while drinking coffee or hanging out with friends

No "rewards" for hard things - no more "if I finish this assignment I'll grab a piece of chocolate"

Minimize "cheap" dopamine hits like sugar (insert other vice)

1/
For things I enjoy (eating, lifting, walking): no "layering on" other enjoyable things like music, podcasts, or social media

For things that aren't enjoyable (difficult work assignment, running): I ask Siri to flip a coin to see whether I will add a layer like music or not

Control your dopamine or it will control you

9/ Finally: this is using the scientific method as a MODEL. There is no replacement for quality science and  clinical trials

Take your results with a grain of salt.

8/ Ask yourself: "is the juice worth the squeeze"

Do the benefits you gain far outweigh the costs? 

Example: phosphatidylserine supplements cost $$$ and side effects exist. If the improvement is only 5%, it may not be worth it.

7/ Remember:

Correlation does not equal causation, try to distill what drove the result. 

Only test one variable at a time.

Control placebo if you can (sugar pills for one week, with a friend's help). But know placebo is ok if there is no cost.

6/ Report conclusions

Be honest with yourself and look at the data objectively. Was your hypothesis validated?

Example: Phosphatidylserine improved my restfulness score.

5/ Analyze data 

This is where your wearable becomes valuable! Review your data to see if one variable drove the other. 

Example: During the phosphatidylserine week, restfulness score w/ supplement was X compared to Y in the placebo, and  Z in the baseline.

4b/ 
Example: 4 week period - benchmark week 1, placebo week 2 or 3, phosphatidylserine week 3 or 2, back to normal week 4

(you can order sugar pills online for placebo, see if a friend can setup a blind test for you)

4a/ Test with experiment

Use your wearable to track throughout:
Track a benchmark period. Pick a timeframe that makes sense (e.g. if you're testing body fat, 1-2 months makes sense, less if testing sleep). Keep everything else exactly the same. Track a post-test period 

cont...

3/ Hypothesis 

A hypothesis is a statement about the relationship between two or more variables. I like to pick one thing to add/change and one measurement variable.

Example: 400 mg phosphatidylserine improves my restfulness score in the @ouraring app.

https://t.co/TZihd1dpip

2/ Research topic area

Explore the space - what are the latest studies (I use pubmed), what are some practitioners saying? How can you measure it? What are some levers?

Example: How is sleep quality measured, what are some behaviors and supplements that affect sleep quality...

1/ Question/observation

Start with a question you want answered or an observation you want to understand.

Example: How can I improve my sleep?
